p: Evaluation of the rheological properties of the dough is an important factor that evaluates the flour quality because it studies the physical properties of the hydrated gluten that is formed during kneading [ 17]. The behavior of dough during kneading can be predicted from the farinograms. Typical bread flour presents stability of 10 min and a developing time of 3 min, while the content of water ranges between 55–60% [ 18, 19]. To evaluate the dough workability, an alveogram was obtained. Typical bread flour presents strength between 120–160 × 10 4 J, with an equilibrium (P/L) ranging between 0.4–0.6 [ 20, 21]. In our study, the flours obtained from both treated and untreated grains showed similar farinograms and alveograms, suggesting that the essential oils had no significant effects on the rheological properties of the dough ( Table 6 and Table 7).
